'}, {'created': '2019-07-13 05:04:37.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] Test PDF documentation build

Based on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/601659/

Inline sample config files are dropped to pass PDF doc build.
They still can be viewed via direct links, so it would be no problem.

The following configurations are made for a better PDF document.

- tocdepth for latex is explicitly set to 3 for better navigation
  in the generated PDF. The default was 1 and we cannot provide
  enough information in PDF TOC.
  (neutron.sty is used as it is not a good idea to use
   latex_elements['preamble'] to specify multiple latex commands.)
- The module index is disabled as the neutron document does not
  generate a full module index and it shows only partial entries.
  'makeindex' and 'printindex' are set to empty in latex_elements.
- 'Search' section is shown in index.rst only when the builder is 'html'
  as this section uses a form and makes sense only for HTML doc.

Known issues around PDF build:

- Inline sample config file of neutron.conf triggers latex error
  "Dimension too large". The workaround is to drop inline sample
  config files (see above).

- Relative links to files under _static directory are broken.
  RST/HTML documents are placed in sub directories, but
  in case of PDF build all documents are merged into a single
  LaTeX file at the top directory. This causes a filepath mismatch.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I6f1614a643efa7fad3c2a6ce5692d6873ca0ebd0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-13 05:06:29.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: PDF documentation build

The following changes are made for a better PDF document.

- Inline sample config files are dropped to pass PDF doc build.
  They still can be viewed via direct links, so it would be no problem.
- tocdepth for latex is explicitly set to 3 for better navigation
  in the generated PDF. The default was 1 and we cannot provide
  enough information in PDF TOC.
  (neutron.sty is used as it is not a good idea to use
   latex_elements['preamble'] to specify multiple latex commands.)
- The module index is disabled as the neutron document does not
  generate a full module index and it shows only partial entries.
  'makeindex' and 'printindex' are set to empty in latex_elements.
- 'Search' section is shown in index.rst only when the builder is 'html'
  as this section uses a form and makes sense only for HTML doc.

Known issues around PDF build:

- Inline sample config file of neutron.conf triggers latex error
  "Dimension too large". The workaround is to drop inline sample
  config files (see above).
- Relative links to files under _static directory are broken.
  RST/HTML documents are placed in sub directories, but
  in case of PDF build all documents are merged into a single
  LaTeX file at the top directory. This causes a filepath mismatch.

Based on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/601659/

Change-Id: I6f1614a643efa7fad3c2a6ce5692d6873ca0ebd0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-13 06:30:57.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: PDF documentation build

The following changes are made for a better PDF document.

- Inline sample config files are dropped to pass PDF doc build.
  They still can be viewed via direct links, so it would be no problem.
- tocdepth for latex is explicitly set to 3 for better navigation
  in the generated PDF. The default was 1 and we cannot provide
  enough information in PDF TOC.
- The module index is disabled as the neutron document does not
  generate a full module index and it shows only partial entries.
  'makeindex' and 'printindex' are set to empty in latex_elements.

The existing contents (mainly the top page) are reorganized a bit
for a better TOC of the generated PDF document:

- The top page of the documentation is simplified only with toctree
  to avoid almost duplicated entries in the TOC of the PDF documentation.
  The current TOC for PDF doc seems to use section titles as the first
  level and title of linked pages as the second level. They are almost
  same and the generated TOC would be redundant.
- The link to the API reference in the top page was moved
  to a subdirectory so that PDF TOC can include it.
- 'Search' section is shown in index.rst only when the builder is 'html'
  as this section uses a form and makes sense only for HTML doc.

Known issues around PDF build:

- Relative links to files under _static directory are broken.
  RST/HTML documents are placed in sub directories, but
  in case of PDF build all documents are merged into a single
  LaTeX file at the top directory. This causes a filepath mismatch.
  In addition, relative links do not work after downloading
  the PDF document. This needs community-wide discussion.
- Inline sample config file of neutron.conf triggers latex error
  "Dimension too large". The workaround is to drop inline sample
  config files (see above).

Based on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/601659/

Change-Id: I6f1614a643efa7fad3c2a6ce5692d6873ca0ebd0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-13 08:18:16.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: PDF documentation build

'}, {'created': '2019-08-19 16:53:55.000000000', 'message': "PDF documentation build

The following changes are made for PDF document.

- Sample config/policy files are skipped for PDF doc build.
  We hit several problems around verbatim of inline samples
  in neutron, nova and others, so we decided to skip them now.
  Downloadable links also should be avoided in PDF doc
  as PDF doc is expected to work alone.
- tocdepth for latex is explicitly set to 3 for better navigation
  in the generated PDF. The default was 1 and we cannot provide
  enough information in PDF TOC.
- The module index is disabled as the neutron document does not
  generate a full module index and it shows only partial entries.
  'makeindex' and 'printindex' are set to empty in latex_elements.
- python dependencies and bindep.txt are based on
  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/601659/.

The existing contents (mainly the top page) are reorganized a bit
for a better TOC of the generated PDF document:

- The top page of the documentation is simplified only with toctree
  to avoid almost duplicated entries in the TOC of the PDF documentation.
  The current TOC for PDF doc seems to use section titles as the first
  level and title of linked pages as the second level. They are almost
  same and the generated TOC would be redundant.
- The link to the API reference in the top page was moved
  to a subdirectory so that PDF TOC can include it.
- 'Search' section is shown in index.rst only when the builder is 'html'
  as this section uses a form and makes sense only for HTML doc.

Story: 2006099
Task: 35127
Change-Id: I6f1614a643efa7fad3c2a6ce5692d6873ca0ebd0

commit_message:
PDF documentation build

The following changes are made for PDF document.

- Sample config/policy files are skipped for PDF doc build.
  We hit several problems around verbatim of inline samples
  in neutron, nova and others, so we decided to skip them now.
  Downloadable links also should be avoided in PDF doc
  as PDF doc is expected to work alone.
- tocdepth for latex is explicitly set to 3 for better navigation
  in the generated PDF. The default was 1 and we cannot provide
  enough information in PDF TOC.
- The module index is disabled as the neutron document does not
  generate a full module index and it shows only partial entries.
  'makeindex' and 'printindex' are set to empty in latex_elements.

The existing contents (mainly the top page) are reorganized a bit
for a better TOC of the generated PDF document:

- The top page of the documentation is simplified only with toctree
  to avoid almost duplicated entries in the TOC of the PDF documentation.
  The current TOC for PDF doc seems to use section titles as the first
  level and title of linked pages as the second level. They are almost
  same and the generated TOC would be redundant.
- The link to the API reference in the top page was moved
  to a subdirectory so that PDF TOC can include it.
- 'Search' section is shown in index.rst only when the builder is 'html'
  as this section uses a form and makes sense only for HTML doc.

Story: 2006099
Task: 35127
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/664555
Change-Id: I6f1614a643efa7fad3c2a6ce5692d6873ca0ebd0

(6 comments)

Partial review.

Overall I really like where you're going with this.

For at least two reasons I'd like to see the monolithic __init__ broken up into smaller methods.
- So it's not so monolithic.
- So the delta is smaller and more scrutable.

Basically, the from_* @classmethodZ stay almost the same, just be come instance-level helpers (mostly s/cls/self/g) that you would call from __init__.

A couple of other notes inline. Mainly, we still need to be careful to have big warnings around merge_resources, because what it's doing is still severely broken for nested providers."}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-08-06 22:53:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-06 17:55:24.000000000', 'message': "scheduler: Flatten 'ResourceRequest.from_extra_specs', 'from_image_props'

The 'ResourceRequest' object sources information from three different
attributes of an instance: the instance's image metadata properties,
the instance's flavor, this flavor's extra specs. It's possible for a
user to override resources requested via the flavor using flavor extra
specs (e.g. using the 'resources:VCPU=N' extra spec), and it's possible
to override traits requested via the flavor extra specs using image
metadata (e.g. using the 'traits_required=foo' metadata property). This
means there's an implicit hierarchy present:

- Traits: image metadata > flavor extra specs
- Resources: flavor extra specs > flavor

Previously, we pulled information from the flavor extra specs and image
metadata using two classmethods, 'from_extra_specs' and
'from_image_props', but this required a lot of glue code in between to
ensure this hierarchy was maintained. Stop doing this, preferring to
centralize everything in one location. This results in fewer LoC and a
more grokable implementation, and will make things much easier when we
start handling 'PCPU's here.

Part of blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: Ic0e6bc47b79711b38b2d4dabaeb5ae1dbaf2b18a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-08-06 18:26:58.000000000', 'message': "scheduler: Flatten 'ResourceRequest.from_extra_specs', 'from_image_props'

commit_message:
scheduler: Flatten 'ResourceRequest.from_extra_specs', 'from_image_props'

The 'ResourceRequest' object sources information from three different
attributes of an instance: the instance's image metadata properties,
the instance's flavor, this flavor's extra specs. It's possible for a
user to override resources requested via the flavor using flavor extra
specs (e.g. using the 'resources:VCPU=N' extra spec), and it's possible
to override traits requested via the flavor extra specs using image
metadata (e.g. using the 'traits_required=foo' metadata property). This
means there's an implicit hierarchy present:

- Traits: image metadata > flavor extra specs
- Resources: flavor extra specs > flavor

Previously, we pulled information from the flavor extra specs and image
metadata using two classmethods, 'from_extra_specs' and
'from_image_props', but this required a lot of glue code in between to
ensure this hierarchy was maintained. Stop doing this, preferring to
centralize everything in one location. This results in fewer LoC and a
more grokable implementation, and will make things much easier when we
start handling 'PCPU's here.

Part of blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: Ic0e6bc47b79711b38b2d4dabaeb5ae1dbaf2b18a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

Why not use openstacksdk? It's more convenient and you'll be able to throw away all microversion handling."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 13:13:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

@dtantsur - I'm glad you asked. It is my understanding (from mordred) that using openstacksdk requires some plumbing in nova that we don't have yet.

I actually don't know any more than that, including what the plumbing would comprise, how hard it would be to work up, etc.

I'm also not at all familiar with openstacksdk yet, so I'm intimidated by the prospect of digging into all of that."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-03-15 13:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

My understanding is that as soon as you have a keystoneauth session, you should be able to get openstacksdk for free. Like this: https://github.com/openstack/metalsmith/blob/master/metalsmith/_provisioner.py#L59.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-03-15 13:40:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I think it's a great idea to use SDK - and I think we're definitely solid enough in the API that I'm comfortable supporting nova (although I will want to add a Zuul job that runs nova tests with sdk tip just to be sure)

Before I say things about impl - one of the nice features we have in sdk is the existence of Adapter objects already. So when we implement "get me an SDK connection" we can at the same time change "get me an adapter" to just get a connection and then return the adapter from it. (this way we can test the SDK plumbing with the existing usage of adapters)

From an IMPL perspective:

The main thing we need is a function that can take a CONF and return a Connection. It can be inspired by the current "get session from CONF" code (although will need to be a little different) If we're aiming for soon, this function can go into Nova at first (since we're in feature freeze for sdk already) but it should ultimately live in the openstack.config module. What it wants to do is translate ALL of the settings for ALL of the services listed in CONF into the appropriate input parameters for a CloudRegion. The largest amount of logic there will be translating from service name to service type - but we have os-service-types already, which is a dependency of sdk, so it'll be availble to use.

Once we have that, making a Connection will be sometihng like:

  cloud_region = openstack.config.get_cloud_region_from_conf(CONF)
  conn = openstack.connection.Connection(
      session=session, cloud_region=cloud_region)

Once you have that conn, you can do things like:

  conn.baremetal.get()

to make ironic calls. Or

  conn.image.get()

to make glance calls. BUT - you can also use the higher-order methods when they exist. dtantsur has great ironic methods that do microversion negotiation for you already - which should greatly simplify your use.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 14:34:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

For reference, continued this discussion in IRC: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-03-15.log.html#t2019-03-15T13:25:24

In summary, we will probably want to drop this patch, or at least put it on hold for a while until the sdk plumbing is in place (and possibly proven via a more convenient service like placement) whereupon it would be reworked to take advantage of the sdk instead of ksa.

I'll upload another PS with pep and partial UT fixes because why not."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 14:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 14:35:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Workflow-1

Holding this pending SDK plumbing.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 19:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

SDK plumbing started via [1] (which depends on openstacksdk work at [2]).

This could conceivably by stacked on top of [1] and reworked to use the baremetal bits of the sdk...

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643664/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643601/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 20:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-15 21:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-12 21:44:42.000000000', 'message': "WIP/PoC: Bypass ironicclient for node.get

We would like nova not to use ironicclient, but instead to invoke the
ironic API directly through a ksa adapter.

This commit sets up (part of) the framework to do that, and uses it for
one such API call, 'node.get'.

Some details:

A new class is introduced in client_wrapper. It is currently called
_IronicClient, and is currently instantiated from within
IronicClientWrapper to minimize the surface area of the change. It will
eventually be called IronicClient, and will be instantiated directly by
the ironic driver once IronicClientWrapper is removed.

The IronicClientWrapper was already importing ksa config opts, and, as
long as the (deprecated) api_endpoint opt wasn't used, constructing a
ksa adapter with them. Previously, this was just being used for its
endpoint, which was passed to ironicclient, and the rest was thrown
away.

Now we save that ksa adapter in the _IronicWrapper, which uses it to
invoke the ironic API directly.

The _IronicClient class is introduced with a single method, node_get,
which invokes the GET /nodes/{node_ident} operation. Future commits will
add methods for the other API calls used by the ironic driver. Once
they're all implemented, we can remove IronicClientWrapper and promote
_IronicClient. Until then, IronicClientWrapper's `call` method is hacked
to look for and invoke the _IronicClient method corresponding to its
first argument before falling back to the actual ironicclient call.

Change-Id: I641f1b07beb0c44001f8018326105bcb3fc603cf

"}, {'created': '2019-03-14 20:53:18.000000000', 'message': "WIP/PoC: Bypass ironicclient for node.get

We would like nova not to use ironicclient, but instead to invoke the
ironic API directly through a ksa adapter.

This commit sets up (part of) the framework to do that, and uses it for
one such API call, 'node.get'.

Some details:

A new class is introduced in client_wrapper. It is currently called
_IronicClient, and is currently instantiated from within
IronicClientWrapper to minimize the surface area of the change. It will
eventually be called IronicClient, and will be instantiated directly by
the ironic driver once IronicClientWrapper is removed.

The IronicClientWrapper was already importing ksa config opts, and, as
long as the (deprecated) api_endpoint opt wasn't used, constructing a
ksa adapter with them. Previously, this was just being used for its
endpoint, which was passed to ironicclient, and the rest was thrown
away.

We would have liked to save that ksa adapter in the _IronicWrapper,
which would use it to invoke the ironic API directly. But there are
problems with that, explained in the code; so we just construct a fresh
adapter for _IronicWrapper in the way we're eventually going to want to
do it anyway when IronicClientWrapper goes away.

The _IronicClient class is introduced with a single method, node_get,
which invokes the GET /nodes/{node_ident} operation. Future commits will
add methods for the other API calls used by the ironic driver. Once
they're all implemented, we can remove IronicClientWrapper and promote
_IronicClient. Until then, IronicClientWrapper's `call` method is hacked
to look for and invoke the _IronicClient method corresponding to its
first argument before falling back to the actual ironicclient call.

Change-Id: I641f1b07beb0c44001f8018326105bcb3fc603cf

"}, {'created': '2019-03-15 20:52:58.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/PoC: Use SDK instead of ironicclient for node.get

We would like nova not to use ironicclient, but instead to invoke the
ironic API directly through an openstacksdk connection.

This commit sets up the framework to do that, and uses it for one such
API call, GET /v1/nodes/{node_ident} [1].

The framework simply comprises a new attribute on the IronicDriver,
ironicconn, built using the get_sdk_adapter util. The ironicclient
attribute will go away along with the entire client_wrapper module once
all python-ironicclient calls have been swapped out.

The API call is invoked via the get_node SDK method [2].

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/baremetal/?expanded=show-node-details-detail#show-node-details
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/proxies/baremetal.html#openstack.baremetal.v1._proxy.Proxy.get_node

Change-Id: I641f1b07beb0c44001f8018326105bcb3fc603cf

'}, {'created': '2019-04-08 21:02:50.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/PoC: Use SDK instead of ironicclient for node.get

We would like nova not to use ironicclient, but instead to invoke the
ironic API directly through an openstacksdk connection.

This commit sets up the framework to do that, and uses it for one such
API call, GET /v1/nodes/{node_ident} [1].

The framework simply comprises a new attribute on the IronicDriver,
ironicconn, built using the get_sdk_adapter util. The ironicclient
attribute will go away along with the entire client_wrapper module once
all python-ironicclient calls have been swapped out.

The API call is invoked via the get_node SDK method [2].

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/baremetal/?expanded=show-node-details-detail#show-node-details
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/proxies/baremetal.html#openstack.baremetal.v1._proxy.Proxy.get_node

Change-Id: I641f1b07beb0c44001f8018326105bcb3fc603cf

commit_message:
Introduces SDK to IronicDriver and uses for node.get

We would like nova not to use ironicclient, but instead to invoke the
ironic API directly through an openstacksdk connection.

This commit sets up the framework to do that, and uses it for one such
API call, GET /v1/nodes/{node_ident} [1].

The framework simply comprises a new attribute on the IronicDriver,
ironic_connection, built using the get_sdk_adapter util. The ironicclient
attribute will go away along with the entire client_wrapper module once
all python-ironicclient calls have been swapped out.

The API call is invoked via the get_node SDK method [2].

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/baremetal/?expanded=show-node-details-detail#show-node-details
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/proxies/baremetal.html#openstack.baremetal.v1._proxy.Proxy.get_node

Blueprint: openstacksdk-in-nova
Change-Id: I641f1b07beb0c44001f8018326105bcb3fc603cf

commit_message:
Fix typo in microversion sequence test

The assertion failure message in a microversion sequence test
had a typo. This was not noticed because the test usually
passes and the message is not produced under normal circumstances.

Change-Id: I76cca613e0d89e235f7fc23740dda93bda4ffd15

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-26 00:12:18.000000000', 'message': 'Verify archive_deleted_rows --all-cells in post test hook

We are already running archive_deleted_rows in the gate, but we are
not verifying whether all instance records, for example, were actually
successfully removed from the databases (cell0 and cell1).

This adds the --all-cells option to our archive_deleted_rows runs and
verifies that instance records were successfully removed from all cell
databases.

Related-Bug: #1719487

Change-Id: If133b12bf02d708c099504a88b474dce0bdb0f00
'}, {'created': '2019-07-26 00:20:43.000000000', 'message': 'Verify archive_deleted_rows --all-cells in post test hook

We are already running archive_deleted_rows in the gate, but we are
not verifying whether all instance records, for example, were actually
successfully removed from the databases (cell0 and cell1).

This adds the --all-cells option to our archive_deleted_rows runs and
verifies that instance records were successfully removed from all cell
databases.

It is not sufficient to check only for return code 0 because
archive_deleted_rows will still return 0 when it misses archiving
records in cell databases.

Related-Bug: #1719487

Change-Id: If133b12bf02d708c099504a88b474dce0bdb0f00

commit_message:
Verify archive_deleted_rows --all-cells in post test hook

We are already running archive_deleted_rows in the gate, but we are
not verifying whether all instance records, for example, were actually
successfully removed from the databases (cell0 and cell1).

This adds the --all-cells option to our archive_deleted_rows runs and
verifies that instance records were successfully removed from all cell
databases.

It is not sufficient to check only for return code 0 because
archive_deleted_rows will still return 0 when it misses archiving
records in cell databases.

Related-Bug: #1719487

Change-Id: If133b12bf02d708c099504a88b474dce0bdb0f00

commit_message:
[Trivial]Remove unused helper get_vm_ref_from_name

get_vm_ref_from_name is no longer used after 86f385b955151d2648aa42c42a8489d36e489286,
this is to remove it.

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Note that python35-charm-jobs is retained since this charm is supported
on Xenial.

Change-Id: I92cabba6bba1a64babf36d8f5e9fb3a3c556b777
Story: #2005924
Task: #34228
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678676

commit_message:
encryptors: Deprecate the CryptsetupEncryptor

This encryptor and the underlying plain cryptsetup encryption format it
provides is not widely used, inflexible (no key rotation) and as a
result no longer required in os-brick. This change starts the
deprecation process.

Additional changes will be posted to ensure the retype workflow between
this encryptor and the LUKS based encryptors is well tested ahead of any
removal.

Change-Id: Ibb560da269a2f330526af6761fa509c262e3d361

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-22 00:12:41.000000000', 'message': "Handle websockify v0.9.0 in console proxy

In websockify v0.9.0, the WebSocketServer class moved from the
websockfiy.websocket module to the websockify.websocketserver
module [1], so our import of the top-level module is no longer
sufficient for accessing WebSocketServer [2] when using v0.9.0:

 AttributeError: module 'websockify' has no attribute 'WebSocketServer'

This adds a try_import from the v0.9.0 module location and uses
WebSocketServer from there if the module is present. Otherwise, it will
fall back on the old module location. This way, we are able to run with
websockify v0.9.0 and earlier versions with the same code.

Partial-Bug: #1840788

[1] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/8a697622495fd319582cd1c604e7eb2cc0ac0ef6
[2] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/v0.9.0/websockify/__init__.py

Change-Id: I4a50e2f772101315140df43910be2e3f69a63b73
"}, {'created': '2019-08-22 02:06:46.000000000', 'message': "Handle websockify v0.9.0 in console proxy

In websockify v0.9.0, the 'socket' staticmethod  moved from the
websockfiy.websocket.WebSocketServer class to the
websockify.websockifyserver.WebSockifyServer class [1][2], so our
import of the top-level module is no longer sufficient for accessing
the 'socket' method [3] when using v0.9.0:

 AttributeError: module 'websockify' has no attribute 'WebSocketServer'

This adds a try_import from the v0.9.0 location and uses
WebSockifyServer from there if the module is present. Otherwise, it
will fall back on the old location. This way, we are able to run with
websockify v0.9.0 and earlier versions with the same code.

Partial-Bug: #1840788

[1] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/8a697622495fd319582cd1c604e7eb2cc0ac0ef6
[2] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/e47591f4aaa0221a187d3ea2f61c7ab5bb93ed54
[3] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/v0.9.0/websockify/__init__.py

Change-Id: I4a50e2f772101315140df43910be2e3f69a63b73
"}, {'created': '2019-08-22 16:06:00.000000000', 'message': "Handle websockify v0.9.0 in console proxy

In websockify v0.9.0, the 'socket' staticmethod  moved from the
websockfiy.websocket.WebSocketServer class to the
websockify.websockifyserver.WebSockifyServer class [1][2], so our
import of the top-level module is no longer sufficient for accessing
the 'socket' method [3] when using v0.9.0:

 AttributeError: module 'websockify' has no attribute 'WebSocketServer'

This adds a try_import from the v0.9.0 location and uses
WebSockifyServer.socket if the module is present. Otherwise, it
will fall back on the old location. This way, we are able to run with
websockify v0.9.0 and earlier versions with the same code.

Partial-Bug: #1840788

[1] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/8a697622495fd319582cd1c604e7eb2cc0ac0ef6
[2] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/e47591f4aaa0221a187d3ea2f61c7ab5bb93ed54
[3] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/v0.9.0/websockify/__init__.py

Change-Id: I4a50e2f772101315140df43910be2e3f69a63b73

commit_message:
Handle websockify v0.9.0 in console proxy

In websockify v0.9.0, the 'socket' staticmethod  moved from the
websockfiy.websocket.WebSocketServer class to the
websockify.websockifyserver.WebSockifyServer class [1][2], so our
import of the top-level module is no longer sufficient for accessing
the 'socket' method [3] when using v0.9.0:

 AttributeError: module 'websockify' has no attribute 'WebSocketServer'

This adds a try_import from the v0.9.0 location and uses
WebSockifyServer.socket if the module is present. Otherwise, it
will fall back on the old location. This way, we are able to run with
websockify v0.9.0 and earlier versions with the same code.

Partial-Bug: #1840788

[1] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/8a697622495fd319582cd1c604e7eb2cc0ac0ef6
[2] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/commit/e47591f4aaa0221a187d3ea2f61c7ab5bb93ed54
[3] https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/v0.9.0/websockify/__init__.py

Change-Id: I4a50e2f772101315140df43910be2e3f69a63b73

[{'created': '2019-07-24 17:15:23.000000000', 'message': "Rework 'numa_usage_from_instances'

This function was confusing. Its name suggests it is expecting multiple
instances from which to parse usage, when in reality it was only ever
called with a single instance NUMA topology. Rename and rework the
function, using a better function name, a better docstring and
normalized variable names both in this function and two related
functions.

Change-Id: Ic6f5f89ffaaff1bdc213c1d2b8b56aad99bdd594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Rework 'hardware.numa_usage_from_instances'

This function was confusing. Its name suggests it is expecting multiple
instances from which to parse usage, when in reality it was only ever
called with a single instance NUMA topology from non-test code. Rename
and rework the function, using a better function name, a better
docstring and normalized variable names both in this function and two
related functions, in order to make the whole thing a little more sane.
Any tests that relied on the ability to pass multiple instance NUMA
topology objects in are reworked to simply call the function multiple
times.

Change-Id: Ic6f5f89ffaaff1bdc213c1d2b8b56aad99bdd594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 18:17:15.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'hardware.instance_topology_from_instance'

Yet another function that has outstayed its welcome. This one had to
handle random object types that may have had a 'numa_topology' field or
key, which, if present, contained an instance NUMA topology in either
string, dict or object form. This was only called in two places, both of
which don't need this complexity as described below, meaning we can
remove this function.

nova/objects/request_spec.py

  The 'from_components' static method and '_from_instance' helper
  function were both using this, by way of a call to
  '_from_instance_numa_topology'. However, the former always receives an
  actual 'NUMATopology' object, while the latter always receives an
  instance, albeit possibly in serialized form. We add a check to handle
  the serialized form and we're done.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py

  The 'estimate_instance_overhead' method can receive a Flavor object,
  and Instance object, or a dict. The former was being handled
  separately but the latter weren't. Start handling them separately
  instead of calling the wrapper.

Change-Id: I5ded32a1cd33ab5b64ffa73fcfeb76683eb97df7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-21 13:52:23.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'hardware.instance_topology_from_instance'

commit_message:
Remove 'hardware.instance_topology_from_instance'

Yet another function that has outstayed its welcome. This one had to
handle random object types that may have had a 'numa_topology' field or
key, which, if present, contained an instance NUMA topology in either
string, dict or object form. This was only called in two places, both of
which don't need this complexity as described below, meaning we can
remove this function.

nova/objects/request_spec.py

  The 'from_components' static method and '_from_instance' helper
  function were both using this, by way of a call to
  '_from_instance_numa_topology'. However, the former always receives an
  actual 'NUMATopology' object, while the latter always receives an
  instance, albeit possibly in serialized form. We add a check to handle
  the serialized form and we're done.

Change-Id: I5ded32a1cd33ab5b64ffa73fcfeb76683eb97df7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove 'hardware.host_topology_and_format_from_host'

Since Id93a01fcaeaa6b95e49ded6b81249325126d012b, the 'numa_topology'
field of the 'nova.scheduler.host_manager.HostState' object will always
be a 'NUMATopology' object, meaning we don't need to call the
aforementioned function. With that call removed, we have no callers left
and can remove the function itself entirely.

Change-Id: I72cee470ac0bf380c9cd8d8f5c7d703e5374f65a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 18:17:15.000000000', 'message': "Remove 'hardware.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance'

This method was intended to update a host NUMA topology object based on
the usage from one or more instances. It was horribly complex because we
store host and instance NUMA topologies in fields of many other objects,
some o.vo-based and others not, and some of those fields aren't using
the correct type. It would be much easier have a method that expected
only 'NUMATopology' (host) and 'InstanceNUMATopology' (instance) objects
and we did any conversion necessary to get these before the call. We
already have such a function, 'numa_usage_from_instances', which was
actually being called by 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' once it
finished fishing through object soup, and there are only to non-test
callers to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' to be updated. This means
we can make the below changes and remove this awful function once and
for all.

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py

  This call to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' was passing in a
  'ComputeNode' object, whose 'numa_topology' field is of type
  'StringField' meaning the value could be in string format, and a dict,
  'usage', which may have contained a 'numa_topology' key. Now we simply
  check if the usage dict's 'numa_topology' field is set and, if so,
  pass that and the ComputeNode's 'numa_topology' field into the
  'numa_usage_from_instances' function, stopping to covert the former to
  an object if necessary.

nova/scheduler/host_manager.py

  This call to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' was passing in a
  'HostState' object, which is a plain old object with a 'numa_topology'
  field, and a mostly empty 'Instance' object with only the
  'numa_topology' field set. Now we just pass the 'numa_topology' fields
  from both objects to 'numa_usage_from_instances' function, once again
  adding an earlier check to ensure the former is converted from a
  string if so necessary.

Change-Id: Id93a01fcaeaa6b95e49ded6b81249325126d012b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

  'StringField' meaning the value could be in string format, and a dict,
  'usage', which may have contained a 'numa_topology' key. Now we simply
  check if the usage dict's 'numa_topology' field is set and, if so,
  pass that and the ComputeNode's 'numa_topology' field into the
  'numa_usage_from_instances' function, stopping to covert the former to
  an object if necessary.

nova/scheduler/host_manager.py

  This call to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' was passing in a
  'HostState' object, which is a plain old object with a 'numa_topology'
  field, and a mostly empty 'Instance' object with only the
  'numa_topology' field set. Now we just pass the 'numa_topology' fields
  from both objects to 'numa_usage_from_instances' function, once again
  adding an earlier check to ensure the former is converted from a
  string if so necessary.

Change-Id: Id93a01fcaeaa6b95e49ded6b81249325126d012b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove 'hardware.get_host_numa_usage_from_instance'

This method was intended to update a host NUMA topology object based on
the usage from one or more instances. It was horribly complex because we
store host and instance NUMA topologies in fields of many other objects,
some o.vo-based and others not, and some of those fields aren't using
the correct type. It would be much easier have a method that expected
only 'NUMATopology' (host) and 'InstanceNUMATopology' (instance) objects
and we did any conversion necessary to get these before the call. We
already have such a function, 'numa_usage_from_instances', which was
actually being called by 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' once it
finished fishing through object soup, and there are only to non-test
callers to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' to be updated. This means
we can make the below changes and remove this awful function once and
for all.

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py

  This call to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' was passing in a
  'ComputeNode' object, whose 'numa_topology' field is of type
  'StringField' meaning the value could be in string format, and a dict,
  'usage', which may have contained a 'numa_topology' key. Now we simply
  check if the usage dict's 'numa_topology' field is set and, if so,
  pass that and the ComputeNode's 'numa_topology' field into the
  'numa_usage_from_instances' function, stopping to covert the former to
  an object if necessary.

nova/scheduler/host_manager.py

  This call to 'get_host_numa_usage_from_instance' was passing in a
  'HostState' object, which is a plain old object with a 'numa_topology'
  field, and a mostly empty 'Instance' object with only the
  'numa_topology' field set. Now we just pass the 'numa_topology' fields
  from both objects to 'numa_usage_from_instances' function, once again
  adding an earlier check to ensure the former is converted from a
  string if so necessary.

Change-Id: Id93a01fcaeaa6b95e49ded6b81249325126d012b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

The new names will make much more sense in a future patch.

Part of blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: Ie99347c47ec054cde34a6dc058660967805bd4a3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-07-23 13:17:19.000000000', 'message': "cellv2: fix update_cell to support cell0

necessary to update the cells.

The 'nova-manage cellv2 update_cell' command can automatically read

commit_message:
cellv2: fix update_cell to support cell0

After an update of the database URL due to a driver change, it's
necessary to update the cells.

The 'nova-manage cellv2 update_cell' command can automatically read
nova's config to correctly instruct the transport and database URLs.

Currently, this command is bugged for cell0 since for this cell there
are special cases:

- We should not configure transport URL by passing 'none:///' instead.
- A specific '_cell0' suffix should be added to the database URL.

This commit is fixing the issue so it's now possible to ask
nova-manage to update cells even the cell0.

The workaround is for example pass --transport_url=none:/// and
--database_url=db:///nova_cell0

Future works would be to refuse passing --transport_url and check the
validity of --database_url when cell0 is requested.

Related-Bug: #1835037

- Use a class-level mock for common mocks
- Use 'fixtures.MockPatch' instead of 'fixtures.MonkeyPatch'
- Move exception handling for the 'ovs_plug' and 'ovs_unplug' functions

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Address nits from privsep series

- Add missing coverage for 'iptables_set_rules' and 'iptables_get_rules'
- Use a class-level mock for common mocks
- Use 'fixtures.MockPatch' instead of 'fixtures.MonkeyPatch'
- Move exception handling for the 'ovs_plug' and 'ovs_unplug' functions
  to the functions themselves, allowing us to include the full command
  attempted in the exception message
- OvsConfigurationFailure is renamed to OVSConfigurationFailure

Change-Id: Ib8bb847598db2a6b8de95fdb222279cd22eaabcc
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Document archive_deleted_rows return codes

The archive_deleted_rows command has a specific set of return
codes for both errors and flow control so we should document
those in the CLI guide.

A FIXME is left in the code because of the odd case of when
you could get 1 back meaning "we archived some stuff" or
"something really bad happened".

Change-Id: Id10bd286249ad68a841f2bfb3a3623b429b2b3cc

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-21 19:24:04.000000000', 'message': "Make a failure to purge_db fail in post_test_hook.sh

Currently, the 'purge_db' call occurs before 'set -e', so if and when
the database purge fails (return non-zero) it does not cause the script
to exit with a failure.

This moves the call after 'set -e' to make the script exit with a
failure if the database purge step fails.

Closes-Bug: #1840967

Change-Id: I6ae27c4e11acafdc0bba8813f47059d084758b4e
"}]
commit_message:
Make a failure to purge_db fail in post_test_hook.sh

Currently, the 'purge_db' call occurs before 'set -e', so if and when
the database purge fails (return non-zero) it does not cause the script
to exit with a failure.

This moves the call after 'set -e' to make the script exit with a
failure if the database purge step fails.

Closes-Bug: #1840967

Change-Id: I6ae27c4e11acafdc0bba8813f47059d084758b4e

'}, {'created': '2019-08-21 13:46:05.000000000', 'message': 'Make memtune parameters consistent with libvirt docs and code

LibvirtConfigGuestMemoryTune created a <memtune> element with
attribute "units", although the libvirt docs mention that it should be
"unit":

    https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsMemoryTuning

It did not cause any issues because libvirt actually accepts both,
but domains defined using "units" are automatically converted to
use "unit".

Similarly, libvirt will automatically convert "K" to "KiB".

So rename the attribute from "units" to "unit", and use the same "KiB"
unit format as elsewhere in the code, e.g. LibvirtConfigCapsNUMACell
and LibvirtConfigGuestMemoryBackingPage.

Change-Id: I1e5a28cd30124a2b08ed732d45e5504b31c97284
'}]
commit_message:
Make memtune parameters consistent with libvirt docs and code

LibvirtConfigGuestMemoryTune created a <memtune> element with
attribute "units", although the libvirt docs mention that it should be
"unit":

    https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsMemoryTuning

It did not cause any issues because libvirt actually accepts both,
but domains defined using "units" are automatically converted to
use "unit".

Similarly, libvirt will automatically convert "K" to "KiB".

So rename the attribute from "units" to "unit", and use the same "KiB"
unit format as elsewhere in the code, e.g. LibvirtConfigCapsNUMACell
and LibvirtConfigGuestMemoryBackingPage.

Change-Id: I1e5a28cd30124a2b08ed732d45e5504b31c97284

commit_message:
Add blocker migration for completing services.uuid migration

The online data migration to add a uuid value to non-deleted
services table records was added in Pike [1]. This change adds
a blocker migration which will make "nova-manage db sync" fail
if the online data migration has not been performed by now so
we can remove that online data migration code in the U release.

[1] I6baf546d7075f7671df0abeb1e7d68372fd177ed

Change-Id: I8927b8a4513dab242d34953d13dd2cc95393dc80

commit_message:
Deprecate Aggregate[Core|Ram|Disk]Filters

The Aggregate[Core|Ram|Disk]Filters have not worked
correctly since ocata, this change deprecates them
for removal next cycle.
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126283.html

Related-Bug: #1804125
Change-Id: Ibfbfdae9e6ec93f772631a84e8969f4e11da8aee

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-02 18:01:12.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Remove unnecessary argument

There '_get_guest_numa_config' function takes an 'allowed_cpus'
argument, but there's only one caller and it's always provided with the
same value. Just get the value directly.

Part of blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: I2dfaf01350b75466db9864311089a06068a79284
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-08-04 20:22:55.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Remove unnecessary argument

There '_get_guest_numa_config' function takes an 'allowed_cpus'
argument, but there's only one caller and it's always provided with the
same value. Just get the value directly.

Part of blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: I2dfaf01350b75466db9864311089a06068a79284
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Remove unnecessary argument

There '_get_guest_numa_config' function takes an 'allowed_cpus'
argument, but there's only one caller and it's always provided with the
same value. Just get the value directly.

Part of blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: I2dfaf01350b75466db9864311089a06068a79284
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 18:17:15.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Remove unnecessary try-catch around 'getCPUMap'

This was added in the original review [1] but seems to be totally
unnecessary: the only reason this can fail is if libvirt version is less
than 1.2.5 [2] or if the ACL checks fail [3]. The former isn't an issue
since our minimum is greater than this and the latter isn't an issue
since that feature is off by default and there's no reason it would be
turned on for a nova host, since nova is a trusted management
application that needs full access to libvirt.

Remove the exception handling and fix a bug with a related exception,
which was attempting to do delayed string interpolation which is only a
thing with the 'logging' library, not exceptions.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/173187/8/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@4480
[2] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/search?l=C&q=.nodeGetCPUMap
[3] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/76be4f5ddac/src/vz/vz_driver.c#L1003

Change-Id: Ia7bfd3e9c8b542beb59a7a01da45a60a6027ea37
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Remove unnecessary try-catch around 'getCPUMap'

This was added in the original review [1] but seems to be totally
unnecessary: the only reason this can fail is if libvirt version is less
than 1.2.5 [2] or if the ACL checks fail [3]. The former isn't an issue
since our minimum is greater than this and the latter isn't an issue
since that feature is off by default and there's no reason it would be
turned on for a nova host, since nova is a trusted management
application that needs full access to libvirt.

Remove the exception handling and fix a bug with a related exception,
which was attempting to do delayed string interpolation which is only a
thing with the 'logging' library, not exceptions.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/173187/8/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@4480
[2] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/search?l=C&q=.nodeGetCPUMap
[3] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/76be4f5ddac/src/vz/vz_driver.c#L1003

Change-Id: Ia7bfd3e9c8b542beb59a7a01da45a60a6027ea37
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
objects: Rename 'nova.objects.instance_numa_topology'

Drop the '_topology' suffix. It's not done for the host NUMA topology
objects (those are found in 'nova.objects.numa') and like that file,
this file holds many 'InstanceNUMA*' objects and not just
'InstanceNUMATopology'. This has annoyed me for years so just go fix the
thing.

Change-Id: I283538771a868747f05721a9207db5717b8b68d3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
overcloud status: return a message if no deployment is found

If "openstack overcloud status" has no deployment, returns a proper
message instead of just None.

Change-Id: Ia884a052223be31e8df9de8ae39dacd1fc3159cd

commit_message:
Add python3 file for additional images

In addition to hardened images
(https://review.opendev.org/#/q/I953c5648ac79dc8a59fd4bc798c21e6e383e1afc)
a python3 file needs to be added to support RHEL 8 for hardened uefi and
realtime-compute images.

Change-Id: Ic4f9a7a6128842f54dc70f51adb74067acc7bc8a

[{'created': '2019-08-27 19:06:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add disco-stein bundle to gate tests

The bundle disco-stein was in the dev bundles because
a bug with the Python 3.7 syntax prevented the success of
the deployment of HA clusters. This bug is fixed, we can
reintegrate disco-stein in the gate bundles.

Other small additions:
- removing sitepackages in tox.ini to avoid test env pollution
- skip_missing_interpreters in tox.ini set to False to avoid false
positives by skipping missing interpreters.

LP Related-Bug: #1823718
Change-Id: Ibad815c50a15aa8df7349262109fcdb2e4a3e341
'}]
commit_message:
Add disco-stein bundle to gate tests

The bundle disco-stein was in the dev bundles because
a bug with the Python 3.7 syntax prevented the success of
the deployment of HA clusters. This bug is fixed, we can
reintegrate disco-stein in the gate bundles.

Other small additions:
- removing sitepackages in tox.ini to avoid test env pollution
- skip_missing_interpreters in tox.ini set to False to avoid false
positives by skipping missing interpreters.

LP Related-Bug: #1823718
Change-Id: Ibad815c50a15aa8df7349262109fcdb2e4a3e341

commit_message:
Add disco-stein bundle to gate tests

This project does not have func tests, however these changes are in line
with a batch of changes over all charms, so I kept the same title for
reference.
Changes:
- removing sitepackages in tox.ini to avoid test env pollution

commit_message:
Avoid pollution and false positives with tox.ini

- Added 'Alternatives' section in lxd-to-nova-lxd-rename.rst too avoid
pep8 error, and fixed other pep8 mistakes
- changing testenv to python3
- removing sitepackages in tox.ini to avoid test env pollution
- skip_missing_interpreters in tox.ini set to False to avoid false
positives by skipping missing interpreters.

Change-Id: Id746fff4bfe7b0dd3ccb2803793f78a194d81355

commit_message:
Don't force verbosity of 1 for config-download

Instead, honor the value of verbosity that was specified on the command
line. This will make the ansible tasks less verbose by default, so that
we don't have to add no_log everywhere which actually ends up hiding
useful output.

Change-Id: Ib5060a3e9679b105c76c3c72011c23aee0093dc1

commit_message:
Add transfer-list --sort argument

Change Idb04f783b2287b2b45d626131648b0005a232fbe to the cinder service
introduced pagination and the ability to sort results for listing volume
transfers. This adds the sort ability to the cinder client.

The service side uses the sort_key and sort_dir that we've deprecated
long ago, but was unfortunately missed when merging this support. Since
we have been giving deprecation warnings for using those for other
operations, this adds support for --sort that internally will convert to
the API's expected sort_key and sort_dir.

Change-Id: I137436c76852cbb974eee87e49712c698cbf081b
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-27 14:19:17.000000000', 'message': "Remove pre-upgrade best-effort online data migrations

The best effort pre-upgrade online data migrations were an attempt to
mitigate possible user errors if users forget to run the online data
migrations explicitly during the previous upgrade. However, they ended
up causing more problems than good:

* If user follows docs, they are unnecessary.

* If the containers for the services aren't running, they will get
  silently ignored already. This was done to facilitate re-runs of
  failed upgrade steps and prevent false failures. If the upgrade
  includes an operating system change, the pre-upgrade migrations will
  simply not run.

* However, if the containers for the services are running but the
  database is not running or is not functional for some reason, the
  migration will be attempted and the upgrade will get stuck. This
  leads to confusing errors not really related to the root cause of
  the problem, and non-straightforward breakages where the fix might
  otherwise be just to re-run the upgrade.

For the above reasons this commit removes the pre-upgrade just-in-case
online data migrations. We should be running them only as documented
in the upgrade workflow.

Change-Id: I5d3cc863f138d4f1a915e8a2060dd9ed1d577f37
Closes-Bug: #1841590
(cherry picked from commit cd23d2054e34f860c3115b5870a98c0c80967392)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove pre-upgrade best-effort online data migrations

The best effort pre-upgrade online data migrations were an attempt to
mitigate possible user errors if users forget to run the online data
migrations explicitly during the previous upgrade. However, they ended
up causing more problems than good:

* If user follows docs, they are unnecessary.

* If the containers for the services aren't running, they will get
  silently ignored already. This was done to facilitate re-runs of
  failed upgrade steps and prevent false failures. If the upgrade
  includes an operating system change, the pre-upgrade migrations will
  simply not run.

* However, if the containers for the services are running but the
  database is not running or is not functional for some reason, the
  migration will be attempted and the upgrade will get stuck. This
  leads to confusing errors not really related to the root cause of
  the problem, and non-straightforward breakages where the fix might
  otherwise be just to re-run the upgrade.

For the above reasons this commit removes the pre-upgrade just-in-case
online data migrations. We should be running them only as documented
in the upgrade workflow.

Change-Id: I5d3cc863f138d4f1a915e8a2060dd9ed1d577f37
Closes-Bug: #1841590
(cherry picked from commit cd23d2054e34f860c3115b5870a98c0c80967392)

There is still no %check section'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-09 16:19:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Answering both Colleen and Dirk,

networking-l2gw tests depend on neutron tests (don't know why), and those are not provided (for a reason, I guess). I can prepare the section but they cant run at the moment.

Regarding python3, neutron dependency, which is python2 only also. Anyway, what would be the approach for the agent and associated systemd service files? I haven't yet seen any example of these being provided both on python2 and python3. At end I see that one or the other is chosen.

Let me know if I am missing something."}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-10 09:55:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> networking-l2gw tests depend on neutron tests (don't know why), and
 > those are not provided 

hmm now that I look at it, they are included just not on their own package. Will check it out."}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-07-10 12:51:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:17:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:22:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

So, status is:

* testrepository is required for testr.
* some tests fail because things from neutron.tests are missing.
* Regarding python3, would it make sense to stay python2 while neutron is python2?'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:39:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-07-10 16:50:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> So, status is:
 > 
 > * testrepository is required for testr.

Agreed, there's no .stestr.conf for this project so we still need testrepository

 > * some tests fail because things from neutron.tests are missing.

Can we resolve this, either by skipping those tests or adding neutron things as BuildRequires ?

 > * Regarding python3, would it make sense to stay python2 while
 > neutron is python2?

I think it would be best to use singlespec to allow this package to build for either python2 or python3, we will need to update neutron to python3 asap anyways. None of the other packages in rpm-packaging explicitly declare skip_python3 even if they are still python2-only so I don't think that should be necessary in any case."}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-11 10:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Can we resolve this, either by skipping those tests or adding
> neutron things as BuildRequires ?

I just realized that there is a separate neutron-test package on our downstream while there is no such thing here. Any idea how that came to be? It means then that we will need differences also for this package.

> I think it would be best to use singlespec to allow this package to
> build for either python2 or python3, we will need to update neutron
> to python3 asap anyways. None of the other packages in
> rpm-packaging explicitly declare skip_python3 even if they are
> still python2-only so I don't think that should be necessary in any
> case.

I used singlespec here combined with the skip_python3 option so it is relatively easy to switch from python2 to python3 in the future. I got this idea directly from the python packaging guidelines:

"Packages that only exist for Python 3 can be left as is, or they can be converted to singlespec, with %define skip_python2 1. This is to ensure that they can build for PyPy or other flavors in the future. The definition should be made at the top of the spec-file."

The issue here is that we bundle systemd unit files with the package. I haven't seen yet an example of a singlespec that provides the systemd unit files for both flavors. All examples I have seen make the choice to do so for one of the flavors, so whats the point really? I can think of ways of achieving it but they are certainly not pretty. Maybe it hasn't occurred to me the good way to do it, so I am open for suggestions. 

So at the end my idea was to prepare the singlespec package but opt for a single flavor just now, and wait and see how things would be solved for neutron (given that any py3 package of this would not work anyway). If you think it would be better to just skip python3 for the systemd section only, then we could do that.

Somewhat related, some distros have already adopted the idea that some files may be duplicated in different subpackages of the same source package and that idea would really come handy for these singlespecs:
https://pagure.io/packaging-committee/issue/138'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-11 10:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-07-11 17:21:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

So testr - fine, thanks for checking. regarding tests, does it work if you pull in the openstack-neutron-test subpackage ? the tests should be available by itself (unless it requires some extra artifact not being installed to run the tests). 

for the python3 topic; https://review.opendev.org/670357 should be switching neutron to python3, so then this one should work'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-11 17:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> regarding tests, does it work
 > if you pull in the openstack-neutron-test subpackage ?

Yes, I will have to do that in our downstream. But that will be a difference vs upstream, I just don't know right now how we handle such differences.

> for the python3 topic; https://review.opendev.org/670357 should be
> switching neutron to python3, so then this one should work

Ok, so it is either python2 or python3, but we will not provide neutron on both pythons at the same time. So basically what I am doing here, choosing right now python2 since it is what we have. We can wait for that patch and just replace "%define skip_python3 1" with "%define skip_python2 1". I also plan to backport this where we will need to stay with python2. I think singlespec is useful here also to keep the differences at a minimum.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-11 17:50:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-12 11:00:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-12 11:04:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-12 11:12:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-12 13:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-18 08:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-18 11:02:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 6876, 'date': '2019-07-18 18:31:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-18 18:55:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

> (2 comments)

I went for the current setup on RDO as reference. It's true that config-dir is not used on other services here but packages do include a README that suggest such a setup and having an additional common dir does make sense to a degree. log-dir option is used for example in the ovsvapp and vsphere agents.

If there is a reference that we should follow, happy to go for it."}, {'account_id': 6876, 'date': '2019-07-18 19:38:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-19 08:48:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-19 08:54:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

> (1 comment)

Agree with that but again tried to keep backward compatibility with the RDO package.

There are other things that bother me about how this has been traditionally packaged, like not having a top package name of openstack-neutron-l2gw and bundling non python files in the python- package.

Maybe we can have some other opinions here?'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:45:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 6876, 'date': '2019-07-22 23:16:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

(1 comment)

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-24 14:13:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > recheck

L27 is package "openstack-neutron". we don't want that because it includes config files that interfere with testing (neutron bug probably). Also, I think that Requires do not satisfy the requirements of %check testing, we need BuildRequires for that.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-24 14:13:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-07-24 14:17:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

> > (1 comment)
 > >
 > > recheck
 > 
 > L27 is package "openstack-neutron". we don't want that because it
 > includes config files that interfere with testing (neutron bug
 > probably). Also, I think that Requires do not satisfy the
 > requirements of %check testing, we need BuildRequires for that.

Here

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6d9283c1bc2878c9f29af45a4543df846f5c293e/neutron/tests/base.py#L364

Netron's BaseTestCase should ignore config file dirs as well, not only config files.'}, {'account_id': 6876, 'date': '2019-07-25 15:57:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6876, 'date': '2019-08-06 22:01:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-08 15:38:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19: Patch Set 18 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-08-09 15:47:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

(5 comments)

looks mostly good. I wonder why we're using singlespec for openstack services though, we normally don't intend to do that.."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-08-09 20:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review-1

see inline'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-12 09:13:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > looks mostly good. I wonder why we're using singlespec for
 > openstack services though, we normally don't intend to do that..

I used singlespec because:

1. singlespec is advertised as a convenient way to easily change between python versions.
2. I plan to backport up to Rocky on py2.
3. I intended to build for py2 initially on master to avoid being blocked by neutron py3 transition and then easily change to py3 with neutron.
4. I think it is easier to maintain in singlespec across releases.

I see it is causing more confusion than it's worth, so I will do separate py2/py3 specs."}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-12 10:26:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-12 11:11:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-08-13 19:44:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-08-13 19:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-08-14 13:18:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

from irc meeting, this was the agreed: 

spec.j2 will be called after pypi name, as usual. main package can be then either mapped by pymod2pkg 
we'll add a subpackage agent and python3-*
it would then be python-networking-l2gw-agent for fedora rendering of the spec file and openstack-something-l2gw-agent for suse
something being neutron or networking, don't care atm)"}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-14 18:38:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-19 10:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 27532, 'date': '2019-08-19 10:23:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

commit_message:
Don't accumulate ansible output uselessly

To not overload mistral, we often call the ansible playbook action with
"trash_output". When that's the case, we can discard stdout immediately,
instead of accumulating it and then discarding it.

Change-Id: Ia3d05d716a8e0a1665f9b9310f7d25370bbcdf8d

commit_message:
Dropping support of 42.3

42.3 will not be maintained anymore and therefore
there is no reason to test it. Users are advised
to upgrade to Leap 15, and we should do the same.

commit_message:
flat_networks - Don't hardcode public network name

Use the PUBLIC_NETWORK_NAME variable instead of hardcoding
it when setting the [ml2_type_flat]/flat_networks option.

Change-Id: I8bfc37089ec90eb06ee41d85744dad0f3f734c16

subject: remove duplicate config files in list
messages:
[{'account_id': 30915, 'date': '2019-08-30 12:36:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-08-30 12:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30915, 'date': '2019-08-30 15:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-08-30 15:13:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

What is the reason for doing this? As far as I'm aware it shouldn't be a problem to have duplicate files in the list.

The specific reason I'm -1'ing is that the ordering of the config files is important[0], and if we do this we lose that completely. It would result in undefined behavior and we can't have that.

0: https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.config/latest/reference/configuration-files.html"}, {'account_id': 30915, 'date': '2019-08-30 16:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> What is the reason for doing this? As far as I'm aware it shouldn't
 > be a problem to have duplicate files in the list.
 > 
 > The specific reason I'm -1'ing is that the ordering of the config
 > files is important[0], and if we do this we lose that completely.
 > It would result in undefined behavior and we can't have that.
 > 
 > 0: https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.config/latest/reference/configuration-files.html

I do it just because i find that there may be duplicate config files.  I don't know that the order of config files is important before. I will abandon this commit. Thanks for your review."}, {'account_id': 30915, 'date': '2019-08-30 16:09:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

'}, {'created': '2019-03-30 06:38:41.000000000', 'message': 'Move eventlet monkey patch code

Eventlet monkey patching is not recommended on top level __init__ [1],
because Apache WSGI module uses own concurrency model [2] and API
service under Apache should be runned without eventlet. This patch
moves eventlet monkey patching code to watcher.cmd module __init__
(like in nova).

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-specs/specs/eventlet-best-practices.html
[2] http://modwsgi.readthedocs.io/en/develop/user-guides/processes-and-threading.html

Change-Id: Ie5cf67429ea9ef8d00dd7348ce288437ea105c08

commit_message:
Move eventlet monkey patch code

Eventlet monkey patching is not recommended on top level __init__ [1],
because Apache WSGI module uses own concurrency model [2] and API
service under Apache should be runned without eventlet. This patch
moves eventlet monkey patching code to watcher.cmd module __init__
(like in nova).

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-specs/specs/eventlet-best-practices.html
[2] http://modwsgi.readthedocs.io/en/develop/user-guides/processes-and-threading.html

Change-Id: Ie5cf67429ea9ef8d00dd7348ce288437ea105c08
